title: Similarity of Information and Collective Action
authors: Deepal Basak, Joyee Deb, Aditya Kuvalekar
abstract:
We study a canonical collective action game with incomplete information.
Individuals attempt to coordinate to achieve a shared goal, while also facing a
temptation to free-ride. Consuming more similar information about the
fundamentals can help them coordinate, but it can also exacerbate free-riding.
Our main result shows that more similar information facilitates (impedes)
achieving a common goal when achieving the goal is sufficiently challenging
(easy). We apply this insight to show why insufficiently powerful authoritarian
governments may face larger protests when attempting to restrict press freedom,
and why informational diversity in committees is beneficial when each vote
carries more weight.
